text: hello there I'm Dylan Simon I'm known
for working on dojo over the past 15
plus years been working with JavaScript
since the late 90s and I'm also an avid
type ster proponent currently work on
dojo I run the half stack conferences
and I'm the info Q JavaScript and web
development news editor and what I do
for info cout which is in tech news site
is I write a lot of content and review a
lot of content about what's new with
JavaScript in the web ecosystem and I
think it's really important in that role
to not just cover like what's new with
react and what's new with angular and
what's new with view and node but to
cover a wide range of things that are
emerging interesting different unusual
and conventional and in my role as
editor about once a year we do a trend
report which is essentially a summary of
what is innovative what's getting
adopted what's been fully adopted and
what's kind of lagging behind or no
longer actively being used for new
projects and this helps us determine
sort of what to focus our news on and
basically determine what to prioritize
because we can't cover everything but we
want to cover as many interesting things
as as possible for our users and to just
also help raise awareness for all the
amazing things that are being built for
the web platform so this time we've
taken our sort of trend report and it
used to all fit on one graph but we've
kind of gone a bit crazy this time and
that we've covered 11 different
subcategories so we have sort of the
language and patterns and standards
itself and that sort of covers things
like which version of Acme script you're
using do you use typescript
things like that too client-side
framework server-side frameworks and
data API is cloud computing api's for
web engineers package management
optimization and bundling web
development testing and Ottoman
automation mobile development
environments and frameworks such as
electron IOT blockchain machine learning
the api's for javascript data
visualization and augmented reality and
mixed reality and virtual reality for of
engineers CSS in general and then web
development code editors IDs and these
aren't necessarily the most
categories but what they do is they
allow us to look at a lot of different
things because for example if you're
looking at is something widely adopted
and you compare it to like front-end
frameworks nothing else comes close
right so if you're looking at like
what's the most popular machine learning
JavaScript API it's not going to be used
anywhere near as much as they react or
nodejs or typescript or use so it's nice
to have these subcategories to filter
things out it's also good to look at
sort of the maturity in the context of
those things so there are some areas
where something that's two years old
might be a laggard and in another space
that might still be an early adopter and
it just kind of depends on the growth
rate in that space we've covered I think
probably more than a hundred different
projects tools and features we cover
webassembly and its growth we cover a
lot of interesting api's and then we use
this to sort of figure out what we're
going to report on and what we're going
to write about so I wouldn't say there
are any particular surprises on this
report other than there are a lot of
things that we covered and it's amazing
how many different things there are and
how many different options there are to
do so many amazing things on the web and
you know I've been particularly
interested lately and some of the IOT
type stuff I recently got this neuro
City fling right here which I'll put on

wrong I just got it i don't really done
much with it yet but what this does is
it reads your thought pattern like
basically your brainwaves I'll you know
the different types of brainwaves and
then lets you do thought computing with
it so my goal eventually is to do this
to think the word bark and make a

think there are a lot of interesting use
cases that could be done without
computing the company that creates this
is actually for example looking at ways
to make it possible to like determine
when your most productive as an engineer
and other really interesting use cases
there's a lot of interesting innovation
in the space it seems like every day
there's something new around web
assembly I saw an announcement recently
about bringing a platform that I thought
was dead back to the web with web
assemblies so there's a lot of really
interesting
locations news cases for that and then
really the sort of atwood's law that if
something complete built in javascript
it likely will be built in javascript to
certainly continues to come true and
evolve over the years so I think it's a
very exciting time to be a JavaScript
developer it can be a bit daunting or a
bit fatiguing at times but we do our
best to help you sort of learn about
what's interesting and the way we write
on Infocom is very to-the-point
news driven trying to help you know like
is this something I should care about or
not and you can determine that by the
few paragraphs we start with to tell you
what is this thing and why is it useful
and what's new about it to help you make
an assessment of well should I consider
something new should I use this is this
worth putting on my radar is this
something I could learn from is this
something I would actually use today and
so forth so I hope you enjoy the new
report we've had a lot of fun putting it
together and we appreciate your feedback
and I'm sure we've missed a lot of
things but you know over do what we can
to cover as many different things as
possible within reason so if there's
something really important that you
think we missed let us know and we'll
hopefully include it next time thanks
and look forward to hearing from you
